units.name: BigMek
units.description: Heavily armoured infantry unit that protects its allies.
units.flavour: Especially talented or popular Mekboyz will soon attract a following, lording it over a growing gang of underlings. A Mek with this much clout is referred to as a Big Mek, and can prove indispensable to the local Warboss with his knowledge of shokk attack guns, force field technology, and tellyporta rigs.

units.name: Battlewagon
units.description: Heavily armoured transport vehicle unit.
units.flavour: Ork Battlewagons rumble to war on a collection of tracks, tyres and massive spiked rollers. Whether lumbering gun-fortresses, bright red speedsters or gaudy rust buckets smeared with Ork glyphs, Battlewagons are massive slabs of motorised junk built to carry big mobs of greenskins into battle. No matter each Battlewagon's individual peculiarities, all fulfil the essential role of armoured attack vehicle. A solid wedge of these mighty tanks can provide a warband with a (somewhat rusty) mailed fist that can be jammed right down the throat of the enemy army.

units.name: Boy
units.description: Basic infantry unit that excels in close combat.
units.flavour: Ork Boyz are the heart and soul of any warband. They charge into battle in a great mass, crashing into the enemy like a green landslide. Bellowing with the joy of battle, mobs of Ork Boyz excel at close quarters where they can hack, bludgeon and stamp their foes into bloody ruin. The average Ork Boy is mean-tempered and exceptionally tough, more than compensating for his lack of intellect with a talent for violence.

units.name: Dakkajet
units.description: Fast and lightly armoured aircraft unit that excels against ground targets.
units.flavour: Streaking into battle through war-scorched skies, a Dakkajet's massive thruster leaves an oily contrail of black smoke in its wake even as its guns spit streams of bullets at the foe. Though not as nimble as the aircraft of some other races, Dakkajets are capable of an incredible turn of speed that makes them a fearsome enemy to face in aerial combat. It also helps that Orks fly like complete headcases.

units.name: BurnaBommer
units.description: Fast and lightly armoured bomber unit that easily scorches large infantry formations in cover.
units.flavour: Burna-bommers are an inevitable by-product of the Orks' love for speed, fire, and the desire to combine these things while killing something. Strapped with as many incendiary bombs and rockets as is physically feasible, Burna-bommers streak low over the battlefield, raining conflagrant death down on tightly-packed enemy infantry.

units.name: Deffkopta
units.description: Versatile skirmisher unit that can fly across obstacles.
units.flavour: Deffkoptas buzz across the battlefield, weaving through the sky on a trail of foul-smelling smoke. As they swoop low over the heads of the enemy, the fiendish Ork flying machines fire punishing salvoes of shot, rokkits and bomms into their midst. Leaving flames and blood-splattered craters in their wake, the Deffkoptas jink erratically away, already hunting for their next victims.

units.name: GargantuanSquiggoth
units.description: Massive fearsome beast unit that crushes enemy troops and serves as a transport.
units.flavour: Squiggoths are Orkoid monstrosities, towering hulks made of little more than muscle and bad temper. They are distantly related to Squigs and have all savagery and single-mindedness of their smaller cousins, but Squiggoths can grow so large that they dwarf tanks and even buildings. Goaded by the Orks that ride on a howdah upon its back, the Squiggoth thuds into battle, the ground tremblind beneath its feet.

units.name: FlashGitz
units.description: Versatile ranged infantry unit.
units.flavour: Amongst the richest and most obnoxious of their warlike breed, Flash Gitz travel the galaxy engaging in acts of outrageous piracy and wanton vandalism. They hire themselves out as mercenaries to Ork warbands, basking in the envy of Boyz jealous of their flashy kit and prodigious dakka. Despite their ostentation, Flash Gitz give a Warboss all the killpower he pays for. Completely lethal in gun battles, boarding actions and the like, a mob of Gitz opening fire is nothing short of cataclysmic. A punishing hail of energy bolts and bullets fills the air, the Flash Gitz' victims coming apart amid sprays of blood and blossoms of flame before the Gitz stomp the life out of anyone left standing.

units.name: Gorkanaut
units.description: Massive heavily armoured walker unit that rains death and destruction upon its opponents.
units.flavour: A Gorkanaut is everything an Ork aspires to be. Massive, tough, loud and destructive, its blocky silhouette looms menacingly over friend and foe alike. From its hulking, orkoid shape to the brutal weapons it wields, a Gorkanaut epitomises the unsubtle brutality of Gork and his no-nonsense way of war. Every Gorkanaut is essentially a massively overbuilt armoured war suit bristling with dakka and packing an armoured claw the size of a Killa Kan.

units.name: Headquarters
units.description: Headquarters unit that represents a city's defenses.
units.flavour: Once a Warboss has amassed an army of a certain size, he can no longer command with the simple cudgelling and swearing his boyz have grown to love. The Boss Tower doubles up as a place for the boss to live and a bully pulpit from which he can bellow at his hordes.

units.name: KillaKan
units.description: Lightly armoured walker unit that scorches its enemies.
units.flavour: The Killa Kans' grot pilots put their relative skill with firearms to good use, blowing the zog out of anything unlucky enough to cross their path. Despite being hardwired into a ten-foot tall killing machine, Killa Kan pilots still retain a good degree of Gretchin cowardice. As a result they still believe in safety in numbers, and have a bad habit of losing their nerve under fire. It is not unheard of for Killa Kans to waddle about in circles or freeze up entirely at the first sign of danger.

units.name: KillBursta
units.description: Super-heavy vehicle with a big kannon and transport assault capacity.
units.flavour: Kill tanks are an Ork heavy tank design based around the twin Ork loves of speed and extreme violence. The Kill Bursta's main gun is an immense, wide-bore siege mortar mounted in the centre of its forward hull, much in the manner of a Space Marine Vindicator, only much, much larger! The huge rocket-boosted ordnance launched by the bursta gun, while appallingly short ranged, is powerful enough to blast a hardened bunker or defensive bastion to smithereens, and has been observed in direct fire shattering Imperial super-heavy tanks in a single shot, based as much on luck as good judgement by its gunners.

units.name: Mek
units.description: Infantry unit that repairs vehicles, clears tiles and founds new cities.
units.flavour: Without Mekboyz, Orks would lack for light, power, transport, and even guns (they lack for sanitation regardless, but that's another story). Whenever an Ork needs something building, be it a shiny new shoota or the boss' new ride, they go straight to the Meks. Furthermore, an Ork with teef to spare will take existing kit to the nearest Mek in the hope of having damage repaired, and maybe some kustomising done. It is a rare day that the customer gets what he asked for, but whatever the Mek turns out will normally be fairly flash all the same.

units.name: MekGun
units.description: Armoured anti-air unit.
units.flavour: The roar of Mek Gunz has heralded the end for many a hapless foe. Spitting out blasts of crackling energy, swatting planes out of the air or crushing their victims in crackling fists of bright green force, these big, clanky field guns have enough dakka to stomp even the toughest targets. Of course, as no self-respecting Ork would be left behind when there's a fight in the offing, crewing the gunz is left to the long-suffering grots.

units.name: Meganob
units.description: Heavy infantry unit.
units.flavour: The richest and most battle-hardened Nobz can become Meganobz by paying a Mek to build them a suit of mega armour. Piston-driven and covered in enough protective plating to turn its wearer into a walking tank, this armour is incredibly expensive. Yet it serves as the ultimate greenskin status symbol. Though other Orks mock the Meganobz for wearing so much armour, only the dullest would do so within earshot. Even a direct hit from a tank round is unlikely to do more than knock a Meganob over, worsening his already foul temper. For many, the only chance of surviving an encounter with an angry Meganob is to outrun him.

units.name: Painboy
units.description: Hero unit that heals and augments allied infantry.
units.flavour: Often referred to by other Orks as Doks, Painboyz are the greenskin equivalent of both surgeons and dentists. They are driven to perform exploratory surgery on living creatures just as Mekboyz are driven to fiddle with machinery. Devious, deranged, and usually covered in gore from head to toe, Painboyz are a menace to friend and foe alike.

units.name: Tankbusta
units.description: Infantry unit that excels against heavily armoured targets.
units.flavour: Tankbustas are Orks who have become completely addicted to the thrill of destroying the armoured fighting vehicles of their foes. Their desire to hunt down and slay the biggest, most dangerous tanks they can find echoes the primal instinct of the big game hunter.

units.name: Warbiker
units.description: Fast skirmish unit with high fire power.
units.flavour: Mobs of Ork Warbikers race into battle at suicidal speeds, exhausts belching greasy clouds of smoke. As they hurtle toward the enemy ranks, the Warbikers fill the air with a murderous storm of shots from their blazing dakkaguns. Surrounded by billowing clouds of smoke and dust, the Warbikers are protected from the worst of the enemy’s return fire – by the time the bikeboyz thunder out of this swirling cloud, they are all but on top of the foe.

units.name: Warboss
units.description: Hero unit that crushes enemies in close combat and inspires allies.
units.flavour: An Ork Warboss is the strongest, toughest, loudest and most violent Ork in his tribe. These massive greenskins seize the lion's share of the loot from every fight, meaning they are usually armed and armoured better than any of their followers. Warbosses are not above making a swift and messy example of anyone whose kit seems shinier or more killy than theirs. They wield absolute authority over their tribe, for greenskin society is based on the idea that might makes right.

units.name: Weirdboy
units.description: Hero unit with versatile psychic powers.
units.flavour: Weirdboyz are the most psychically attuned of all Orks. They are capable of vomiting blasts of Warp energy that can reduce foes to molten goop in seconds. Weirdboyz unconsciously channel the background mental emissions of nearby greenskins. Even a close-run squig-eating contest between two rowdy Boyz will cause waves of energy to pulse through any Weirdboy that strays near. Unless the Weirdboy finds some way to release this pent-up energy his head will explode, detonating the heads of nearby Orks into the bargain. This can prove highly inconvenient.

units.name: Warbuggy
units.description: Fast reconnaissance vehicle unit.
units.flavour: Orks tend toward light, fast vehicles with big guns that can be cobbled together from any junk to hand. Most are crewed by a mad-eyed Ork driver and cackling gunner, with perhaps a grot or two hanging on for dear life. What they lack in survivability, these crude vehicles make up for in speed, numbers and dakka. They encircle the enemy in speeding squadrons, guns blazing wildly while their crew throw their heads back and howl like Madboyz.

buildings.name: Beasts
buildings.description: Building that produces beasts, generates food and influence as well as increases loyalty.
buildings.flavour: Runtherds do much of the heavy lifting in Ork society, overseeing the Grots who build everything, the Squigs who supply almost all resources and the tiny Snots who are both carers and food for the Squigs. However, on these grounds they also oversee larger projects—like training Grotz gun crews and rearing the giant Squiggoths.

buildings.name: Construction
buildings.description: Building that constructs new buildings, generates ore and influence as well as increases population limit.
buildings.flavour: Ork buildings are inelegant constructions of waste materials and any scrap that the Meks don't need. The Grotz aren't known to be good architects, but the Orks don't care so long as they get a good fight.

buildings.name: Colonizers
buildings.description: Building that produces Meks and Mek Gunz as well as generates research.
buildings.flavour: A Mek never knows when inspiration is going to hit and he suddenly needs a Thingummy or a Whatyamacallit for his latest invention. For this reason, a Mek's yard is full of broken-up vehicles, machines and tools in case he needs anything suddenly to hand, with teams of lugubrious Grotz endlessly hauling more stuff in.

buildings.name: Energy
buildings.flavour: It doesn't pay an Ork to look too closely at the generators that power their world. That's because much of the technology that Ork Meks produce is missing key parts and shouldn't actually work—but the massed psychic belief of Orks somehow overrides this.

buildings.name: Headquarters
buildings.flavour: Once a Warboss has amassed an army of a certain size, he can no longer command with the simple cudgelling and swearing his boyz have grown to love. The Boss Tower doubles up as a place for the boss to live and a bully pulpit from which he can bellow at his hordes.

buildings.name: Food
buildings.flavour: Squigz are essential to the survival of the Ork species. A huge variety of these small creatures accompany every Ork, and fill an array of social and technological niches—from acting as wigs, to providing oil, to being eaten as food.

buildings.name: Heroes
buildings.description: Building that produces heroes as well as generates influence and increases loyalty.
buildings.flavour: The Blood Axe Clan of Orks are somewhat shunned by their brethren, for not being 'real Orks'. This is because they've adapted to the proximity of humans over the long-millenia and adopted some very un-Orky behaviour, like Taktiks and Runnin Away. Blood Axe Kommandos have gone one step further, using camouflage to surprise their enemies.

buildings.name: Housing
buildings.flavour: Curiously, the Grotz' Hutz are better than those of the Boyz. Sure, from the outside they look even more ramshackle and run-down, while the inside is still built from garbage festooned with mushrooms, squigs and snotlings. But there's a certain pride and personalisation in the squalor that the Boyz' shacks lack.

buildings.name: Infantry
buildings.description: Building that produces infantry and walkers as well as generates influence.
buildings.flavour: 'What's better than a gun?' asks an Ork. 'A bigga gun', answers another. Shortly before the fight starts, they agree that, even better than the biggest gun, is a big pile of big guns. That's exactly what we have here—Mek-made guns of all shapes and sizes, loosely stacked, ready for a Boy or Killa Kan to grab when the fighting starts.

buildings.name: Influence
buildings.flavour: The Ork psykers known as Weirdboyz are a peril at the quietest of times, given their endless accumulation of Waaagh! energy—and in the middle of a horde, a brain bursting chain reaction is normal. This giant metal pole is the Orks' ingenious answer, earthing the psykers' psychic blasts as long as they're tied to it.

buildings.name: Ore
buildings.flavour: When Orks can't get scrap, they'll instead order their Grot serfs to dig up ore-rich rocks. Whilst the Snakebites are happy to use manual labour and whips, most clans' Meks come up with preposterous and crude inventions for extracting the ore, which have varying degrees of lethality for their unlucky Grot operators.

buildings.name: Research
buildings.flavour: One of the more persistent myths of the Orks is about their long-vanished creators, the 'Brainboyz', who they believe encoded highly advanced technology into the Orks' genes aeons ago. Meks, Doks and Runtherdz are Orks who display this knowledge—and the Fink Tank is a good place to lock 'em until they remember another good idea.

buildings.name: Loyalty
buildings.flavour: Orks don't establish dominance by persuasion, but by brute force. A Nob or Warboss is simply a bigger Ork—and the longer they fight, the bigger they get. Fights for dominance or disputes are often worked out in the ritual pits, entertaining the whole Warband in the process. (It's an unfortunate Ork that confuses these pits with the identical looking 'drops'—the Ork toilets.)

buildings.name: Vehicles
buildings.description: Building that produces wheeled vehicles and aircraft as well as generates research and influence.
buildings.flavour: Though they still love war and big explosions, the Orks known as Speed Freeks love velocity even more. They will extensively and obsessively customise their bikes and aircraft, removing all the safety features, to the point where they're sitting on a giant engine—painted crimson because 'red wunz go fasta'.

upgrades.name: Battlewagon
upgrades.description: Heavily armoured transport vehicle unit.
upgrades.flavour: Ork Battlewagons rumble to war on a collection of tracks, tyres and massive spiked rollers. Whether lumbering gun-fortresses, bright red speedsters or gaudy rust buckets smeared with Ork glyphs, Battlewagons are massive slabs of motorised junk built to carry big mobs of greenskins into battle. No matter each Battlewagon's individual peculiarities, all fulfil the essential role of armoured attack vehicle. A solid wedge of these mighty tanks can provide a warband with a (somewhat rusty) mailed fist that can be jammed right down the throat of the enemy army.

upgrades.name: BattlewagonRokkitLaunchas
upgrades.description: Grants Battlewagons rokkit launchas.
upgrades.flavour: Crude but easy to manufacture, the rokkit launcha is a stout stick with a simple trigger mechanism that allows the Ork at the 'safe' end to fire a dodgy-looking rokkit in the general direction of the enemy.

upgrades.name: AmmoRunt
upgrades.description: Grants Big Meks, Flash Gitz and Mek Gunz the ability to increase their ranged accuracy.
upgrades.flavour: An ammo runt is a heavily overburdened Gretchin who carries extra ammunition for his master.

upgrades.name: BattlewagonBigShootas
upgrades.description: Grants Battlwagons big shootas.
upgrades.flavour: Shootas are noisy, large-calibre machine guns. They vary wildly in size and design, from those carried by foot-slogging Boyz to long barrelled supa-shootas that are mounted on aircraft. Regardless of their particular design, all shootas are both deafening and deadly.

upgrades.name: Beasts
upgrades.description: Building that produces beasts, generates food and influence as well as increases loyalty.
upgrades.flavour: Runtherds do much of the heavy lifting in Ork society, overseeing the Grots who build everything, the Squigs who supply almost all resources and the tiny Snots who are both carers and food for the Squigs. However, on these grounds they also oversee larger projects—like training Grotz gun crews and rearing the giant Squiggoths.

upgrades.name: Bigbomm
upgrades.description: Grants Deffkoptas the ability to drop anti-infantry bombs.
upgrades.flavour: Blast weapons fire shells, missiles or packets of energy that explode on impact.

upgrades.name: BigMek
upgrades.description: Heavily armoured infantry unit that protects its allies.
upgrades.flavour: Especially talented or popular Mekboyz will soon attract a following, lording it over a growing gang of underlings. A Mek with this much clout is referred to as a Big Mek, and can prove indispensable to the local Warboss with his knowledge of shokk attack guns, force field technology, and tellyporta rigs.

upgrades.name: BlastDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of grenade, missile and blast weapons.
upgrades.flavour: By using a more advanced engraving protocol on the casing, the lethality of explosive is much improved.

upgrades.name: BonusBeastsProduction
upgrades.description: Increases the production output of Runtherd Groundz.
upgrades.flavour:
“We's gonna need a bigger whip.”
— Runtherd Gark Snotsmeer, shortly before a Squiggoth stepped on him

upgrades.name: BonusColonizersProduction
upgrades.description: Increases the production output of Mek Bitz Yards.
upgrades.flavour: When there isn't enough small-sized scrap to hand to build their ungainly creations, Mekboys acquire more by devising weird and wonderful machines which ravage the ruins and wreckage of their conquered worlds.

upgrades.name: BonusInfantryProduction
upgrades.description: Increases the production output of Pile O' Dakkas.
upgrades.flavour:
“Da best shoota I eva made, dat iz. Loadza barrulz, so dat it's ded shooty. 'Sept dat wun, 'cos dat's da skorcha, dat's burny insted. Yeah, good an' propa. An' da bullitz is 'splosiv…dey goez boom inna fings wot you'z shootin.' An' dat button dere…dat's da best bit. Wot it duz, see, iz…iz…oh, zog. Nah, it's nuffin' boss. Nah, you'z don't need ta see wot dat button duz…'onist. Don't push it!”
— Last words, Nazdakka Boomsnik, Mek

upgrades.name: BoltDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of bolt weapons.
upgrades.flavour: Like the Space Marine Kraken bolts, this Mek barrel modification allows this Shoota to hold even larger calibre ammunition, letting the lucky recipient show off by toting an even larger gun that hits even harder.

upgrades.name: BonusVehiclesProduction
upgrades.description: Increases the production output of Kults ov Speed.
upgrades.flavour: Most Ork technology shouldn't work—vital components are often missing or the device is simply impossible. The Ork's single-minded belief—realised in the form of the Waaagh! energy that surrounds them—fills in the gaps. That's why speeding up the production of Ork vehicles and weaponry has almost no effect upon its quality…

upgrades.name: Bosspole
upgrades.description: Further reduces the morale loss of Mob Rule for Big Meks, Boyz, Meganobz, Tankbustas, Warbikers and Warbosses.
upgrades.flavour: Ork Nobz often sport a trophy pole that shows they are not to be messed with. A Nob with a Bosspole often finds it comes in handy when cracking heads to restore some order in the heat of battle.

upgrades.name: BurnaBommer
upgrades.description: Fast and lightly armoured bomber unit that easily scorches large infantry formations in cover.
upgrades.flavour: Burna-bommers are an inevitable by-product of the Orks' love for speed, fire, and the desire to combine these things while killing something. Strapped with as many incendiary bombs and rockets as is physically feasible, Burna-bommers streak low over the battlefield, raining conflagrant death down on tightly-packed enemy infantry.

upgrades.name: CityEnergy
upgrades.description: Increases the energy output of Ork cities.
upgrades.flavour: Green and red lightning arcs between the intricate prongs of these power amplification devices, frying any Greenskin who wanders too near. It's quite the spectator sport, but the technology is missing key components so couldn't possibly bear out the Meks' claims of its increase in energy output—save for the Orks' reality-altering faith that it does.

upgrades.name: CityGrowth
upgrades.description: Increases the production output of Scrap Shedz.
upgrades.flavour:
“Naw, I don't want zogging tweeterz. I want gorkawooferz… wunz that go up ta eleven!”
— Bleeding Ears Merfnik, Goff Warlord and Rocka

upgrades.name: CityLoyalty
upgrades.description: Increases the loyalty output of Ork cities.
upgrades.flavour: There's nothing that so stirs up the vim of an Ork as the sight of their defeated enemies (or their remaining parts) strung up high for all to see.

upgrades.name: CityInfluence
upgrades.description: Increases the influence output of Ork cities.
upgrades.flavour: “I don't knows what dems is, but I wants 'em.”-- Warboss Flashgrub Nitwiz, gazing upon the hammered gold doors of the Basilica Imperialis on Catiline VII

upgrades.name: CityPopulationLimit
upgrades.description: Increases the population limit of Ork cities.
upgrades.flavour: Using the Mek's latest contraptions, the Ork shacks and forges now extend deep beneath the city's surface. Sure, the occasional collapse drags Orks screaming into the depths, but it's worth it for the extra legroom.

upgrades.name: CityResearch
upgrades.description: Increases the research output of Ork cities.
upgrades.flavour: Given that technology is wired into the genes of normal Orks, a smart Warboss will find that dedicating space, manpower and time to locking his Mekz inside a small room full of scrap and ordering them come up with some really good Dakka invariably pays off.

upgrades.name: CityTier3
upgrades.description: Increases the tile acquisition radius of cities.
upgrades.flavour: The Warboss' fame has spread across the entire planet, with the invisible Waaagh! energies paralleling its path. Wherever Orks are freshly-spawned, they feel the irresistible tugging towards the Warboss' cities, which are now sprawled across the nearby landscape in endless slums and shanties.

upgrades.name: Colonizers
upgrades.description: Building that produces Meks and Mek Gunz as well as generates research.
upgrades.flavour: A Mek never knows when inspiration is going to hit and he suddenly needs a Thingummy or a Whatyamacallit for his latest invention. For this reason, a Mek's yard is full of broken-up vehicles, machines and tools in case he needs anything suddenly to hand, with teams of lugubrious Grotz endlessly hauling more stuff in.

upgrades.name: CityTier2
upgrades.description: Increases the tile acquisition radius of cities.
upgrades.flavour: Outside each fortress' original walls, a slum town of Gretchin, Squigs, Snotlings and low-tier Orks has sprung up, whilst the insidious green fungus has spread everywhere, remaking this world in the Orks' genetic image.

upgrades.name: Construction
upgrades.description: Building that constructs new buildings, generates ore and influence as well as increases population limit.
upgrades.flavour: Ork buildings are inelegant constructions of waste materials and any scrap that the Meks don't need. The Grotz aren't known to be good architects, but the Orks don't care so long as they get a good fight.

upgrades.name: CreatePermanentOrkoidFungusOnDeath
upgrades.description: Causes units to create permanent orkoid fungus when they die.
upgrades.flavour:
“Exhibit 27: a single 'spore' of xenos species #0451 'Ork'. Acolytes, you should note the fungoid texture and microhomuncular structures. We theorise that these 'spores' generate new 'Orks' in any sufficiently fertile setting. When an Ork reaches maturity (typically 30 minutes after emergence) it emits these constantly—but they are released en masse at the moment of death. Please don't drop it.”
— Lecture transcripts, Grigomen “Orklover” Delr, Rogue Trader and amateur Xenologist

upgrades.name: Dakkajet
upgrades.description: Fast and lightly armoured aircraft unit that excels against ground targets.
upgrades.flavour: Streaking into battle through war-scorched skies, a Dakkajet's massive thruster leaves an oily contrail of black smoke in its wake even as its guns spit streams of bullets at the foe. Though not as nimble as the aircraft of some other races, Dakkajets are capable of an incredible turn of speed that makes them a fearsome enemy to face in aerial combat. It also helps that Orks fly like complete headcases.

upgrades.name: Deffkopta
upgrades.description: Versatile skirmisher unit that can fly across obstacles.
upgrades.flavour: Deffkoptas buzz across the battlefield, weaving through the sky on a trail of foul-smelling smoke. As they swoop low over the heads of the enemy, the fiendish Ork flying machines fire punishing salvoes of shot, rokkits and bomms into their midst. Leaving flames and blood-splattered craters in their wake, the Deffkoptas jink erratically away, already hunting for their next victims.

upgrades.name: EavyArmour
upgrades.description: Increases the armour of Boyz and Warbosses.
upgrades.flavour: Ork 'eavy armour is hammered out of scrap iron, sheet metal and the looted battle-plate of fallen foes. Though its fit is dubious, 'eavy armour provides a solid defence for its wearer.

upgrades.name: DakkajetSupaShoota
upgrades.description: Grants Dakkajets a supa shoota.
upgrades.flavour: Shootas are noisy, large-calibre machine guns. They vary wildly in size and design, from those carried by foot-slogging Boyz to long barrelled supa-shootas that are mounted on aircraft. Regardless of their particular design, all shootas are both deafening and deadly.

upgrades.name: ExtraInfantryArmour
upgrades.description: Increases the armour of infantry.
upgrades.flavour: To any other race, Ork armour seems ridiculous: great lumps of thick metal plates, attached by cables, nails and nonsensical apparatuses, painted gold by lumpen Meks and grotz. But with a little bit of Ork belief, it works like a charm.

upgrades.name: ExtraVehicleArmour
upgrades.description: Increases the armour of vehicles.
upgrades.flavour: When a Mek is faced with a Warboss angry that his buggies and battlewagons keep getting blown up, he'll rapidly order his grots to dig out some scrap and nail extra armour anywhere it fits. He knows the Speed Freeks will soon enough peel it off, after all.

upgrades.name: FlashGitz
upgrades.description: Versatile ranged infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: Amongst the richest and most obnoxious of their warlike breed, Flash Gitz travel the galaxy engaging in acts of outrageous piracy and wanton vandalism. They hire themselves out as mercenaries to Ork warbands, basking in the envy of Boyz jealous of their flashy kit and prodigious dakka. Despite their ostentation, Flash Gitz give a Warboss all the killpower he pays for. Completely lethal in gun battles, boarding actions and the like, a mob of Gitz opening fire is nothing short of cataclysmic. A punishing hail of energy bolts and bullets fills the air, the Flash Gitz' victims coming apart amid sprays of blood and blossoms of flame before the Gitz stomp the life out of anyone left standing.

upgrades.name: Flyboss
upgrades.description: Increases the ranged accuracy of Dakkajets against flyers, jetbikes and skimmers.
upgrades.flavour: Flybosses are ace pilots who have survived more dogfights than they can count (even when using their toes).

upgrades.name: Gorkanaut
upgrades.description: Massive heavily armoured walker unit that rains death and destruction upon its opponents.
upgrades.flavour: A Gorkanaut is everything an Ork aspires to be. Massive, tough, loud and destructive, its blocky silhouette looms menacingly over friend and foe alike. From its hulking, orkoid shape to the brutal weapons it wields, a Gorkanaut epitomises the unsubtle brutality of Gork and his no-nonsense way of war. Every Gorkanaut is essentially a massively overbuilt armoured war suit bristling with dakka and packing an armoured claw the size of a Killa Kan.

upgrades.name: GrabbinKlaw
upgrades.description: Grants Battlewagons the ability to immobilize enemy ground vehicles.
upgrades.flavour: In their pursuit of ever-larger Power Klaws, Ork Meks occasionally make ones that are simply too large for even the most over-sized Boss or Deff Dread. These are mounted on vehicles, where they are used to immobilise enemy vehicles or perform outrageous handbrake turns.

upgrades.name: GrotRiggers
upgrades.description: Grants Warbuggies, Killa Kans, Battlewagons, Gorkanauts and Kill Burstas passive hitpoint regeneration.
upgrades.flavour: Whether hurriedly re-attaching gubbinz with rivet guns, or just getting out and pushing, a crew of grot riggers can help to keep an Ork vehicle in the fight long after it should have fallen apart.

upgrades.name: HammerOfWrath
upgrades.description: Grants Deffkoptas, Gargantuan Squiggoths, Gorkanauts, Killa Kans and Warbikers the ability to perform more devastating attacks.
upgrades.flavour: Many warriors hurl themselves headlong into combat, seeking to crush or trample the foe.

upgrades.name: HealingRate
upgrades.description: Increases the healing rate of units.
upgrades.flavour: Through the co-operation of a team of Bad Doks and Runtherdz, your Warlord has prescribed a new, 'more Orky' diet, to make the boyz bigger and stronger, quicker. Whether the cold Oil Squigs for breakfast and Faceeater Squigs for dinner actually has any physical effect is immaterial—the boyz believe it, and that makes it work.

upgrades.name: Heroes
upgrades.description: Building that produces heroes as well as generates influence and increases loyalty.
upgrades.flavour: The Blood Axe Clan of Orks are somewhat shunned by their brethren, for not being 'real Orks'. This is because they've adapted to the proximity of humans over the long-millenia and adopted some very un-Orky behaviour, like Taktiks and Runnin Away. Blood Axe Kommandos have gone one step further, using camouflage to surprise their enemies.

upgrades.name: KillaKan
upgrades.description: Lightly armoured walker unit that scorches its enemies.
upgrades.flavour: The Killa Kans' grot pilots put their relative skill with firearms to good use, blowing the zog out of anything unlucky enough to cross their path. Despite being hardwired into a ten-foot tall killing machine, Killa Kan pilots still retain a good degree of Gretchin cowardice. As a result they still believe in safety in numbers, and have a bad habit of losing their nerve under fire. It is not unheard of for Killa Kans to waddle about in circles or freeze up entirely at the first sign of danger.

upgrades.name: Housing
upgrades.description: Building that increases population limit.
upgrades.flavour: Curiously, the Grotz' Hutz are better than those of the Boyz. Sure, from the outside they look even more ramshackle and run-down, while the inside is still built from garbage festooned with mushrooms, squigs and snotlings. But there's a certain pride and personalisation in the squalor that the Boyz' shacks lack.

upgrades.name: KillBursta
upgrades.description: Super-heavy vehicle with a big kannon and transport assault capacity.
upgrades.flavour: Kill tanks are an Ork heavy tank design based around the twin Ork loves of speed and extreme violence. The Kill Bursta's main gun is an immense, wide-bore siege mortar mounted in the centre of its forward hull, much in the manner of a Space Marine Vindicator, only much, much larger! The huge rocket-boosted ordnance launched by the bursta gun, while appallingly short ranged, is powerful enough to blast a hardened bunker or defensive bastion to smithereens, and has been observed in direct fire shattering Imperial super-heavy tanks in a single shot, based as much on luck as good judgement by its gunners.

upgrades.name: Loyalty
upgrades.description: Building that increases loyalty.
upgrades.flavour: Orks don't establish dominance by persuasion, but by brute force. A Nob or Warboss is simply a bigger Ork—and the longer they fight, the bigger they get. Fights for dominance or disputes are often worked out in the ritual pits, entertaining the whole Warband in the process. (It's an unfortunate Ork that confuses these pits with the identical looking 'drops'—the Ork toilets.)

upgrades.name: Meganob
upgrades.description: Heavy infantry unit.
upgrades.flavour: The richest and most battle-hardened Nobz can become Meganobz by paying a Mek to build them a suit of mega armour. Piston-driven and covered in enough protective plating to turn its wearer into a walking tank, this armour is incredibly expensive. Yet it serves as the ultimate greenskin status symbol. Though other Orks mock the Meganobz for wearing so much armour, only the dullest would do so within earshot. Even a direct hit from a tank round is unlikely to do more than knock a Meganob over, worsening his already foul temper. For many, the only chance of surviving an encounter with an angry Meganob is to outrun him.

upgrades.name: MekGun
upgrades.description: Armoured anti-air unit.
upgrades.flavour: The roar of Mek Gunz has heralded the end for many a hapless foe. Spitting out blasts of crackling energy, swatting planes out of the air or crushing their victims in crackling fists of bright green force, these big, clanky field guns have enough dakka to stomp even the toughest targets. Of course, as no self-respecting Ork would be left behind when there's a fight in the offing, crewing the gunz is left to the long-suffering grots.

upgrades.name: MeleeDamage
upgrades.description: Increases the armour penetration of melee weapons.
upgrades.flavour: When Orks think about upgrades, they don't think very hard. Mega-armour, Gigashootas… and bigga choppas. If you can carry it, you can swing it, and if you can swing it, you can hit someone with it.

upgrades.name: OrkoidFungusFood
upgrades.description: Increases the food output of tiles with orkoid fungus.
upgrades.flavour: The tiny Snotlings, like all Orkoids, are derived from the same base fungus genetic structure. Unlike other Orkoids though, particularly lazy Snotlings can settle back into the fungus patch, and revert to become giant half-mushroom creatures, a particular delicacy for their larger Ork brethren.

upgrades.name: Painboy
upgrades.description: Hero unit that heals and augments allied infantry.
upgrades.flavour: Often referred to by other Orks as Doks, Painboyz are the greenskin equivalent of both surgeons and dentists. They are driven to perform exploratory surgery on living creatures just as Mekboyz are driven to fiddle with machinery. Devious, deranged, and usually covered in gore from head to toe, Painboyz are a menace to friend and foe alike.

upgrades.name: OrkoidFungusBonusHealingRate
upgrades.description: Increases the healing from orkoid fungus.
upgrades.flavour: Once the Ork fungal spores are well-established across a planet, they can resemble forests—albeit, comprised of immense mushrooms, spewing out feral Orks, Grots and Squigs.

upgrades.name: RedPaintJob
upgrades.description: Increases the damage of Warbuggies, Battlewagons, Dakkajets and Burna-Bommers.
upgrades.flavour: Orks believe that a vehicle painted red can outstrip a similar vehicle that isn't. As odd as it may seem, they're not wrong.

upgrades.name: MightMakesRight2
upgrades.description: Increases the influence gain of units dealing damage.
upgrades.flavour: When a Waaagh! is powerful enough, it has something like a multiplying effect, with every blow struck further enhancing the leaking psychic field, in a sort of ultra-violent Orky feedback loop.

upgrades.name: Scavenger2
upgrades.description: Increases the amount of salvaged ore when killing enemy units.
upgrades.flavour: A well organised Runtherd will have trained his Grots to gather and sort scrap for the Orks, as well as avoiding the more dangerous shell casings and munitions.

upgrades.name: SkorchaMissile
upgrades.description: Grants Burna-Bommers anti-infantry missiles that ignore cover.
upgrades.flavour: Skorcha missiles are 'fire and ferget' weapons used by Burna-bommer pilots to flush enemy infantry out of cover. Their warheads explode in sprays of chemical flame that burns white hot and makes a mockery of the mightiest fortifications.

upgrades.name: Stikkbomb
upgrades.description: Grants infantry the ability to throw anti-infantry grenades.
upgrades.flavour: The lethal storm of shrapnel from these grenades drives opponents further under the cover for a few precious moments, allowing attackers more time to close in and, hopefully, get the first blow in against a disoriented foe.

upgrades.name: TankbustaBomb
upgrades.description: Grants Tankbustas the ability to throw anti-armour bombs.
upgrades.flavour: Tankbusta bombs are fusion charges designed to burn through an armoured hull in a matter of seconds.

upgrades.name: Tankbusta
upgrades.description: Infantry unit that excels against heavily armoured targets.
upgrades.flavour: Tankbustas are Orks who have become completely addicted to the thrill of destroying the armoured fighting vehicles of their foes. Their desire to hunt down and slay the biggest, most dangerous tanks they can find echoes the primal instinct of the big game hunter.

upgrades.name: Vehicles
upgrades.description: Building that produces wheeled vehicles and aircraft as well as generates research and influence.
upgrades.flavour: Though they still love war and big explosions, the Orks known as Speed Freeks love velocity even more. They will extensively and obsessively customise their bikes and aircraft, removing all the safety features, to the point where they're sitting on a giant engine—painted crimson because 'red wunz go fasta'.

upgrades.name: Weirdboy
upgrades.description: Hero unit with versatile psychic powers.
upgrades.flavour: Weirdboyz are the most psychically attuned of all Orks. They are capable of vomiting blasts of Warp energy that can reduce foes to molten goop in seconds. Weirdboyz unconsciously channel the background mental emissions of nearby greenskins. Even a close-run squig-eating contest between two rowdy Boyz will cause waves of energy to pulse through any Weirdboy that strays near. Unless the Weirdboy finds some way to release this pent-up energy his head will explode, detonating the heads of nearby Orks into the bargain. This can prove highly inconvenient.

upgrades.name: Warbiker
upgrades.description: Fast skirmish unit with high fire power.
upgrades.flavour: Mobs of Ork Warbikers race into battle at suicidal speeds, exhausts belching greasy clouds of smoke. As they hurtle toward the enemy ranks, the Warbikers fill the air with a murderous storm of shots from their blazing dakkaguns. Surrounded by billowing clouds of smoke and dust, the Warbikers are protected from the worst of the enemy’s return fire – by the time the bikeboyz thunder out of this swirling cloud, they are all but on top of the foe.
